column4: Is it possible to purchase a license to use libdvdcss or something on linux? I know of a small OEM who wants to include it.
i belive theres a 'legal' codec pack you can buy. but i never looked into it. 'feundo' or somthing like that was its name
thanks. I think this is BS and would never pay for it. But as an OEM, they can't just include it :-\
from a legal point of view. they may not be able to include it anyway... (legal things are always so illogical)
fluendo has a OEM section
but does it actually include dvd.. or is it just other codecs. :)
looking
he is thinking about making a quick script that gives a disclaimer and lets the user install it
for some reason you are prompted to download codecs. With dvds, you are not told what the problem is.
totem has always been weird that way.. one reason i use VLC :)
vlc also needs libdvdcss...
if you are lucky it does download the codecs ..
last i checked it was built in.. but i rarely play comercial dvds
last I checked, it wasn't...
someone asked about it here a while ago. And when he installed it it worked.
nor do I. I pirate anyways. No need to deal with css :-P
I don't know. It could be that ubuntu intentionally does not compile it in.
I don't have a windows system handy to test it on...
that also may be the issue.. i always use vlc from various PPA's
chrome has it, chromium does not (I think)
I remember using aptproxy awhile ago. Is it better?
its newer. and has some other features i belive
ok, thanks
